Learning Objective: NEWTON'S LAWS
Recognize when Newton's First Law applies
Recognize inertial and non-inertial reference frames
Explain the difference between Fnet and ma
Recognize objects in equilibrium
Apply Newton's 2nd Law to calculate the acceleration or the force
Verify that the net force on the FBD and the acceleration are consistent
Draw or identify FBD showing the two opposite forces that come from the mutual interaction
FORCES
Represent the common forces in a FBD
Relate weight and mg
Apply expression for universal gravity
Calculate the elastic restoring force
Calculate the tension
Calculate the normal force
Calculate the kinetic friction force
Calculate the static friction force
Identify when F_s = \mu_s * N
NEWTON's LAWS WITH CONSTRAINTS
Identify the system and the internal/external forces and interactions
Calculate constraint forces (normal force, tension and static friction) given constrained acceleration(s)
Represent constraint conditions mathematically (pulleys, contact, string, inclines, etc.)
KINEMATICS - DEFINITIONS
Define the coordinate system, the position and the displacement vectors
Calculate the average velocity, the instantaneous velocity and speed
Calculate v and a for different scenarios
Interrelate displacement, velocity and acceleration in multiple representations (graphical, diagrammatic, mathematical)
1-D KINEMATICS
Solve problems that feature 1D motion with v=const
Solve problems that feature 1D motion with a=const.
Calculate x(t), v(t) and a(t) by differentiating and integrating
Graph changing motion
2-D KINEMATICS
Apply the constant velocity and the constant acceleration model to solve projectile motion problems
Solve problems in which an object has different motions in consecutive time intervals
Solve problems that deal with the motion of more than one object
Draw the tangential velocity, centripetal acc and net force for an object undergoing circular motion
Calculate the tangential velocity, centripetal acc and net force for an object undergoing uniform circular motion
Relate the tangential acceleration and angular acceleration
Find the direction of the acc graphically
LINEAR MOMENTUM
Calculate momentum for a system of particles (analytically and graphically)
Calculate the impulse from a time-varying force
Calculate Impulse from average force
Relate momentum and impulse
Identify situations in which we can apply conservation of momentum
Calculate the CM position for multi-body system
Determine the Motion of Center of Mass
Apply dp/dt = Fext
Obtain differential equation by applying momentum and impulse at t and t + \Delta t
Mass flow
Compare and Contrast Agent of change for Momentum and Energy
Corresponding formulas: J = \int F(t)dt vs W = \int F^{nc} dr

Calculate the elastic potential energy

ROTATIONAL KINEMATICS

Interrelate angular position, velocity, and acceleration
Vector Representation of Angular Motion including a not parallel to \omega
Velocity of points on rotating translating rigid body

ROTATIONAL DYNAMICS

Find the magnitude and direction of the torque about a point due to any force
Apply tau=I alpha
Calculate moment of inertia from mass distribution
Apply the Parallel Axis Theorem
Rotational and Translational Equilibrium
KINETIC ENERGY OF ROTATION

Find the kinetic energy of a rotating, translating rigid body
ANGULAR MOMENTUM

ORBITS
